Kali demonstrates the restraining of short people by spitting spiderweb on Kyrin in child form, and wraps her up in a spider cocoon so she cannot move at all. Aviana is interested, spits on the ground, doesn't seem to work. Kali slices Kyrin free with exceptional dagger skills. We imagine if Kali wanted to hurt Kyrin, Kyrin would have been dead last week.

Kali can use ZA WARUDO with needles and a Time Stop spell. Aviana knows this, and confidently says Kali would not hurt a fly. I think Kali EATS flies. No offense.

pages.name: Fyeywild Adventure 1
pages.content:
I found myself in a dense and sad mushroom forest,the first couple of weeks I tried to find myself a way out but whit little effect.

What i did find however. Was a small, slightly less sad mushroom hut I could use as shelter.

The hut must have belonged to a sad wizard who stumbled into the Feywild at some point judging by the pile of bones and clothing found on the floor next to the table.

after some days with no complains from the Wizard i assumed he didn't need his dusty spell book anymore and I took the liberty to translate some of his spells into more sensible pictures.

Unfortunately I didn't have much time to study his spells before I was interrupted by a group of 3 grumpy Redcaps who apparently gotten lost in the sad forest.

With my quick thinking I put on my trusty Redcap-hat and pretended to be one of them. And they agreed to believe me if they also lived in the mushroom hut.

It sounded like a fine deal to me, which it was until dinner time arrived.

When after a democratic vote on what we should have for dinner (With 3 votes against one), I was selected as the main course.

Luckily I had already set up my traditional Distraction trap made of a bed sheet a rope and lots of ash from the fireplace.

It gave me just enough time to wall my housemates inside the hut with my newfound spell and quickly flee into the sad forest again.

pages.name: 3 Month Timeskip
pages.content:
I bumped in to a Warlock goblin Named Antx and his blacksmith brother Prantx, They had used an unholy ritual to bond their souls together and as a result stuck together when the curse teleports them.

Unfortunately it also seemed to make it so that if one got hurt it would affect the other equally.

Even tho we didn't have many days together. We did have time to attend some big party in the city and share some knowledge about traps and magic between each other,

Unfortunately we had to end the party early for it seemed that Antx and Parnatx also got drunk twice as fast.

so as a finally we drunkenly tested some of our new knowledge in something called the "Trade"-district,

I don't know why they call it the trade district if you are not allowed to trade knowledge in there.

They did seem okay with trading a big box of stuff for us to leave tho so that was a nice trade.

It was a nice timing to because of all the angry guards that turned up, I wouldn't want to stay much longer anyway.

I went to the fay-wild twice, First time a landed in Mennons Court,

I did have some time to ask about my curse and learned some things about the Hag Elsa and apparently some deal she made with Mennon to free him from the Shadowfell.

He also made me participate in some kind of duel with a Dwarf who had asked for some kind of favor. He fought with great honor,

but that was a grave mistake made by him. After the battle i was rewarded some new spells by Mennon.

The second time I went back home to the fay-wild I found myself in company of some Satyrs which i traded some of the items found in the Trade district for more useful things.

pages.name: Plex adventures 2
pages.content: Plex stumbling upon a moonlit clearing where a covey of ethereal nymphs danced around an ancient, gnarled tree, their laughter echoing like the tinkling of bells. A capricious nymph named Luna took a liking to the goblin's sapphire cloak, which gleamed under the silvery moonbeams. She attempted to coax it from him, offering a dance and a whispered secret in return. However, plex had a secret of his own - a lightning quick goat he used it to escape her grasp, leaving her bewitched and the nymphs baffled, as they searched the clearing for their vanished guest.

pages.name: Spider Recipe
pages.content:
Ingredients

4 servings

2 cups canola or vegetable oil

1 Giant death spider

1 cup tempura batter

1 teaspoon smoked paprika

Preparation

  1. Step 1

    In a deep saucepan or deep-fat fryer, heat the oil to 350°F.

    Step 2

    With a sharp knife, sever and discard the abdomens from the giant Spider. Singe off any of the spider's body hairs with a crème brûlée torch or butane cigarette lighter.

    Step 3

    Dip each spider into the tempura batter to thoroughly coat. Use a slotted spoon or your hands to make sure each spider is spread-eagled (so to speak) and not clumped together before dropping it into the hot oil.

    Step 4

    Deep-fry the spiders, one at a time, until the batter is lightly browned, about 1 minute. Remove each spider from the oil and place it on paper towels to drain.

    Step 5

    Use a sharp knife to cut each spider in two lengthwise. Sprinkle with the paprika and serve. Encourage your guests to try the legs first and, if still hungry, to nibble on the meat-filled mesothorax, avoiding the spider's paired fangs, which are tucked away in the head region.

pages.name: Draconic Poem - Translated to Common
pages.content:
In timeless age, gods forged the plane,
their craft divine, their essence chained.

From plane's own core, the gods are born,
their being shaped, their fate is sworn.

Tiamat and Bahamut, twins gods of old,
in hatred's grip, their conflict bold.

Their clash laid waste, no corner spared,
the plane engulfed, a realm ensnared.

Their last embrace, their breaths entwined,
life sparked anew, from death combined.

Hate's demise, a sacred birth,
ten Aspects rose, from ashes' worth.

In temples grand, their praises sung,
their children rose, with banners flung.

The scales aglow, in royal hues,
guiding realms, as kings they choose.

In towers tall, their wisdom spun,
arcane secrets, beneath the sun.

Prosperity bloomed, in realms untold,
mighty kingdoms, forged in gold.

Restless hearts, yet craving more,
ambition's fire begins to soar.

For power sought beyond the skies,
a thirst unquenched, in restless eyes.

He sought to weave a tapestry bold,
reality's threads, his grasp to hold.

Boundaries blurred, the veil grew thin,
material realm, now touched by kin.

Amidst the fray, the world did fall,
as planes converged, in chaos' thrall.

Aspects bound, their sacrifice bold,
seal forged strong, the chaos controlled.

Dragonborn sworn, guardians true,
protect the seal, their purpose due.

Eternal watch, their sacred plight,
knowledge kept, in wisdom's light.

pages.name: Assassination Contract
pages.content:
To the Esteemed Kali Savaris,

I trust this letter finds you in the shadows, where your formidable reputation precedes you. The undercurrents of the underworld speak highly of your... expertise, and it is this very skill that I require.

My cousin, Thelgem Grumblechest, met an untimely demise while on a critical diplomatic mission. His life was taken not by the scoundrels he sought to negotiate with, but by an outsider – an adventurer named Aviana. This harpy possesses abilities that border on the fantastical, growing to a colossal size and causing destruction with the ease of a child stomping on a sandcastle. Though the tales may be inflated, one cannot afford to be dismissive of even the slightest possibility. Thelgem was a mighty warrior and this accursed creature has to be to an awesome foe to have slain him.

Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to track down and eliminate Aviana. She currently resides on the island of Deadlight, in a cabin near the island's sole city, also named Deadlight. Discretion is paramount; while this is a matter of clan honour, it is imperative that the clan's involvement remains concealed as to not taint our diplomatic efforts in the region.

For your successful execution of this task, you will be compensated handsomely with 10,000 gold coins. Consider it not just a payment, but the settling of a grudge. The Grumblechests do not forget, and we do not forgive such transgressions lightly.

The terms are simple: Aviana's life in exchange for the reward.

I await word of your success.

A Vengeful Benefactor

P.S. – To give you an edge, enclosed are the last known sketches of Aviana and a map of Deadlight. May they serve you well.

pages.name: Orders for Immediate Execution
pages.content:
Commander Sicus Ponticus
Deadlight, Quattrus 14th, in the Year of our Emperor 1497

To Gaius Varro, Praetor of the Assassin's Cohort,

Under my command and with the utmost urgency, you are hereby ordered to proceed with the elimination of Fearghas MacAllistair, a dwarf wizard of significant capability, currently residing in a cabin outside the city of Deadlight. The success of this mission is critical, as MacAllistair's creations pose a threat to our strategic interests.

These orders come directly from our superiors, and while I personally find this decision regrettable, given my own favorable opinion of MacAllistair, the necessity of our empire's security must take precedence. His creations, though admirable, are too dangerous to be left unchecked.

You are to execute this task with the highest level of discretion and caution. The implications of our involvement becoming known could severely damage the diplomatic relations between the Taldorian Empire and the nation of Deadlight. Failure to maintain secrecy is not an option.

I trust you resolve this matter swiftly and silently. Upon completion, report back to me directly.

This letter serves as your official orders. Destroy it upon memorization.

By my command,

Commander Sicus Ponticus
High Admiral of the 5th and 6th Imperial Fleets, General of the 4th, 11th, 17th, and 21st Expeditionary Regiments, Imperial Envoy and Chief Overseer of the Empires Diplomatic and Military Affairs in Talia

pages.name: The King's Coaster
pages.content:
As told by Farrow Windwhisper:

Let me spin you a tale few outside the frozen halls of the frost giants know. This is a story passed down by my wife's people, whispered in the winds of glaciers and shared over roaring hearthfires. It is a tale of Utgard-Loki, the cunning king of the frost giants, and how he outwitted one of the most fearsome beings to ever walk this world: the lich Ul'katir.

Now, Ul'katir was no ordinary lich. His power was vast, and his knowledge of arcane secrets… well, it was said he knew more spells than there are stars in the sky. His greatest treasure was a grimoire, a book so filled with ancient and forbidden magic which he guarded jealously, letting no soul touch it. Except... except for the day he crossed paths with Utgard-Loki.

Utgard-Loki, as we all know, is no mere giant. He is a wizard of great renown, a trickster whose wit could cut sharper than any sword. He longed for that grimoire, not because he needed its spells—oh no!—but because he wished to prove that no one, not even a lich, could outmatch his cunning.

And so, Utgard-Loki approached Ul'katir with an offer. "Mighty lich," he said, with a honeyed voice, "I have heard tell of your grimoire, a tome filled with such power that even the gods might tremble. I would ask only to read it—once—so that I, too, might witness its greatness."

Now Ul'katir, ever wary, narrowed his glowing eyes. "And what, pray, would you offer me in return for such a privilege?"

Utgard-Loki smiled that sly smile of his, the one that made you think he already knew how the game would end. "I will give you my most valuable tome. Surely, it will be a worthy trade."

The lich pondered this. A most valuable tome, you say? He thought to himself, "What could the king of giants possess that rivals my power?" But greed is a trap, and so Ul'katir agreed, though not without a safety net. He enchanted his grimoire, binding it with a spell that would return it to him the very moment Utgard-Loki read even a single word.

But Utgard-Loki… well, he is not one to play fair. He handed the lich his "most valuable tome"—and what was it? Not some ancient spellbook, not some arcane artifact. No, it was the teenage diary of Thor himself, which the trickster had stolen years before!

(At this, you might laugh, my friends, and you'd be right to! For this was the same Thor who, in his younger years, wrote poems of unrequited love, tales of his embarrassing misadventures, and dreams of one day growing a beard worthy of his hammer!)

Ul'katir, expecting some great magical work, opened it, only to be greeted by page upon page of Thor’s… rather juvenile musings. The lich, of course, was furious! But before he could act, Utgard-Loki was already gone, his prize grimoire in hand.

Now, what does our trickster do with this mighty tome? Does he read it? Does he unlock its secrets and claim its power for himself?

Nay! He takes it back to his hall, places it on his table, and uses it as a coaster for his drinking horn. Yes, my friends, the great grimoire of Ul'katir, the lich’s greatest treasure, became nothing more than a rest for a giant's mead!

Why, you ask? Because Utgard-Loki knew well the spell laid upon it. He knew the moment he read even a single word, it would vanish, returning to the lich. So instead, he let it sit beneath his horn, never once turning a page, and Ul'katir’s magic was powerless.

But that's not all! Oh no, the tale is not yet done. For you see, Utgard-Loki went a step further in his cleverness. He sought out Thor, yes, the very god whose diary he had given away. And with a whisper of false sympathy, he said to him:

"Thor, my friend, I have terrible news. A foul lich by the name of Ul'katir has your private diary, and he reads it aloud to all who bring him treasures, gems, and scrolls. Tales of your beardless days, your youthful dreams of being a 'great poet'—he spreads it far and wide!"

Thor, as you can imagine, flew into a rage like none had seen before. His thunder echoed across the realms, and with a flash of lightning, he set out to find Ul'katir and reclaim his diary. And Ul'katir, who had been so annoyed with his newfound 'tome,' found himself on the receiving end of the Thunder God's fury.

By the end of it, the lich had no grimoire, no diary, and a very sore skull from the wrath of Mjolnir.

And so, my friends, Utgard-Loki tricked not one, but two mighty beings. The lich, who thought himself clever, and Thor, who thought himself wronged by an innocent lich. All without ever casting a spell or lifting a weapon. Such was the cunning of the frost giant king.

And that, is the story of how the mighty Utgard-Loki made a coaster of a lich's greatest treasure, the grimoire which he proudly uses to this day.

pages.name: Note to future self
pages.content:
Hey, Linzi. So, if you're reading this, you're probably furious and stomping around the tower because you can’t leave until you finish your “basic routine” tasks. You’re probably muttering something about how this is all stupid and unnecessary, and honestly? I get it.

But before you start tearing apart the enchantments (because let’s be honest, I know you’ve thought about it), I need you to remember why you’ve put them up in the first place.

You’re a disaster sometimes. Not with magic—you’re good at that, obviously. But everything else? Everything else? You can barely keep it together. You forget to eat. You forget to sleep. You forget to take care of yourself like a normal person. And, yes, it’s embarrassing to admit, but it’s true.

I mean, look at the plants. How many have you killed so far? And don’t even get me started on the portal you left open a few months ago… What was it? An aboleth, a deva, a horned devil and a very confused goat? You can't keep letting things slide. This is supposed to make sure you stop acting like an incompetent idiot when it comes to the basics.

Here’s the deal. I enchanted the tower to force you to get your act together. Why? Because we both know you won’t do it unless you have no choice. You’re too good at avoiding it, making excuses, or getting caught up in something else. So, no more excuses. No more letting things pile up until it’s overwhelming. This time, you’re going to handle it.

What you need to do before you can leave (and no, you can’t skip any of these):

  • Take a bath. With soap! Not just splashing water on your face. (And please remember to put on clothes afterwards. No more accidents. We don’t need another embarrassing incident.)

  • Eat a meal. A proper one. Not just some random snack. A meal. With veggies. And proteins. And no, potions don’t count as food.

  • Water the plants. Yes, all of them. Especially the one in the study is practically begging for help. You’re the reason it looks like that.

  • Close any portals you’ve opened. Seriously. You don’t want even more stray creature messing up the tower again. On that note, I still haven't found the dust devil that snuck through last week…

  • Keep the tower tidy. All of it! I know, you hate it. But do it anyway. It’s about having a clear mind and a space where you can actually find things! Dust and clutter distract you, and you know it.

  • Finish your experiments. No more half-finished nonsense blowing up in your face because you walked away for “just a minute.” Complete what you start or don’t start at all.

  • Feed your prisoners. If you went through the effort of imprisoning someone, you should at least keep them alive along enough to get whatever information you wanted out of them. So don’t forget about them like last time. I sure hope I learned from that and you better not prove me wrong.

  • Keep the artifact vault locked. If I have to thaw out the entire tower because you forgot to secure that artifact again, I swear I will scream.

I know you’re going to hate this, but it’s necessary. If you want to stop feeling like a complete mess every time you finally come up for air, you need to fix these things. And yeah, I know part of you is reading this and thinking “but I’m too busy” or “I don’t have time for this,” but you do have time. You’re just choosing to ignore it. And that’s what got us here.

So suck it up, do the tasks, and maybe—just maybe—you’ll start feeling less like a walking disaster and more like… well, I don’t know. Someone who has their life together, at least a little.

Hopefully enchanting the tower and locking you inside will finally force yourself into actually being a functional adult. You're too powerful to be this messy and disorganized.

With love (and frustration), Yourself

P.S. I swear if you undo the spell, I’ll re-cast it twice as strong.

pages.name: The Oathsworn of Azgaraz
pages.content:
Azgaraz was a dwarven hold infamous for their 'acceptance' of magic and famous for being skilled monster hunters. Once upon a time their crown prince journeyed to Jotunheim with a large expedition to slay one of the legendary Jormungandr (Ice Wurms/Snakes) there.

While making camp, two of the dwarves went for a walk where they encountered a frost giant child.

The three talked and when the dwarves told the child that they were looking for a Jormungandr, the child told the dwarves of a place it had once seen one. It also told the dwarves story of a frost giant who once killed a Jormungandr, only to be slain by his own kin shortly afterwards and explained that Jormungandr were sacred to frost giants.

When the two dwarves headed back to their expedition, they were in two minds about the information they had just learned. One was exciting for having been told where they could find such a beast, while the other was concerned about the tale they'd been told and worried that a similar fate could await them.

When they returned, they spoke with the crown prince who didn't take the dwarf who voiced his concerns seriously, mocking him in front of the entire expedition and calling him a superstitious coward. The dwarves continued their journey and in the weeks it took them to find the place the child had told them about, the entire expedition treated the dwarf who had voiced his doubts with distain.

When the expedition reached the place, not far from Utgard, they found the Jormungandr and prepared for the fight. To add insult to injury, the crown prince forbade the doubting dwarf to take part in the upcoming battle, stating that a battlefield was no place for someone so soft.

When the battle began, the lone dwarf left behind at camp decided he had enough and went to Utgard to tell the frost giants about their expedition. The frost giants didn't believe him at first, after all why would anyone ever want to kill a Jormungandr, especially someone that short, and sent him away.

The dwarf returned to the camp and was surprised to see that his expedition had already won the battle and slain the mighty creature. When asked why he had abandoned his duty to guard the camp during the battle and where he had gone, the dwarf lied but it raised suspension anyways.

The expedition was celebrating their victory, feasting and drinking in a way only dwarves can, and so they didn't notice the small army of frost giants who had come from Utgard to investigate the dwarf's claims until it was far too late. When they arrived and saw the corpse of their sacred creature and the camp of celebrating dwarves, they went mad with rage and attacked.

Even though the dwarves were taken by surprise, they were all experienced veterans and put up a fierce fight. The crown prince, who had put two and two together, called the doubting dwarf a traitor and slew him before he, as the last dwarf standing, was slain by the frost giant's general soon after. With his dying breath he, in the name of all loyal dwarves under his command, swore revenge upon traitors and frost giants alike.

Thus only one dwarven soul came to be judged by Pharasma that day, as all but the traitor's still linger on that battlefield, bound by their crown prince's oath of revenge.

pages.name: Letter from the Devil
pages.content:
To Fearghas MacAllistar,
Executor of the Binding Agreement,

Pursuant to the terms of our duly executed pact, this correspondence serves as formal notification that the time has come for you to fulfill your obligation. The target of your contractual undertaking, Zacharias, has been notably absent from his primary domicile within the Infernal City of Dis.

It is incumbent upon you to locate and eliminate the aforementioned devil in accordance with the terms agreed upon. As a preliminary resource, you are advised that Zacharias' mansion remains situated along the road connecting the Iron Tower to the Pleasure Gardens. While his residence has been unoccupied for some time, it is a reasonable expectation that pertinent information regarding his current location may be found therein.

Let me remind you that while the specific methodologies of your pursuit are left to your discretion, promptness and efficacy are both implied expectations under our arrangement. Failure to proceed with due diligence would constitute a breach, the consequences of which are presumed to be comprehended and need not be reiterated here.

Should you require clarification of the terms or have need of an intermediary to relay further updates, you may direct your inquiries to the bearer of this letter.

By the Authority Infernal Law,
Zurvan
Adjudicator of Eternal Obligations

pages.name: Duergar Creation Myth
pages.content:
As told by the Dwarves

In the days of yore after Torag had chiseled the Dwarves from solid rock in his image, our ancestors flourished under his tutelage. They built grand halls and forged weapons, armors, and trinkets, as mighty as they were beautiful, and Torag was proud of them. They mined deep, uncovering ever richer veins of ore, but eventually Torag came to them and warned them to not dig any deeper. Something profane lay below, he told them, and our ancestors were wise enough to heed our creator's augury without question.

For some foolish few however, this councel wasn't enough and in their quest to sate their own greed and curiosity, they continued ever deeper, and Torag's heart grew heavy, for he knew they'd soon find what he tried to protect them from. Our ancestors worried for their kin but when the fools returned, our ancestors wept for they realised that they were kin no more. Their skin was burnt and blackened, and their eyes shone like smoldering embers, and when Torag saw this, he came and called them Duergar, and exiled them, for they were his children no longer. The Duergar pleaded for forgiveness but Torag knew their wrong was too great and when he denied them, the Duergar denouced him and crawled down into the deepest reaches of the Underdark, their hearts forever filled with hatred and spite.

As told by the Duergar

In the days of yore after our Father had chiseled the Dwarves from solid rock in his image, we all flourished under his tutelage. We built grand halls and forged weapons, armors, and trinkets, as mighty as they were beautiful, and our Father was proud of us. We mined deep, uncovering ever richer veins of ore, but eventually he came to us and warned us to not dig any deeper. He told us to be afraid. "Something profane lay below", was all he spoke, expecting us to do his bidding with a the blind and unquestioning obedience of a child, and many lucky fools did.

Yet some of us yearned for understanding, striving like any child to one day to become as wise as our beloved Father. And so they forged on and soon found the flame our Father tried to protect us from. It burnt us, charred our skin, and we called it Azgal, the Ebon Fire. We fled in terror back to our Father and brothers, yet upon our return, we were met not with warmth and succor, but with cold contempt and scorn. Confused we pleaded for our Father's forgiveness, but he betrayed us, renounced us, denied us as his children, and called us Duergar. For this is when we finally realised that our beloved Father views us not as children to be raised but as cattle to be kept under a yoke. And our former brothers stood by and watched, their eyes first showing the very look of superiority with which they still look down on us today, for they don't mind being nothing but obedient dogs as long as they get to sit next to our creator's feet.
